sites.name: Duomo di Sant'Andrea
sites.description: Amalfi's stunning 9th-century cathedral dedicated to Saint Andrew, featuring a magnificent Arab-Norman facade with intricate mosaics and a grand staircase. The cathedral houses the relics of Saint Andrew and showcases beautiful Byzantine and Romanesque architecture with stunning views of the town and sea.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round, but early morning offers the best light for photography and fewer crowds. Summer brings more visitors but also longer opening hours.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry to the main church. Small fee for the cloister and crypt. Modest dress required. Check mass times if you want to experience a service.

sites.name: Chiostro del Paradiso
sites.description: The beautiful 13th-century cloister adjacent to Amalfi Cathedral, featuring elegant Moorish-style arches, palm trees, and a peaceful garden. This architectural gem showcases the Arab influence on Amalfi's medieval architecture and provides a serene escape from the bustling town.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most beautiful in spring when flowers are blooming. Summer offers shade from the palm trees. Winter visits are peaceful with fewer tourists.
sites.booking_tips: Small entrance fee required. Combined tickets with cathedral available. Photography allowed. Perfect for quiet contemplation.

sites.name: Marina Grande
sites.description: Amalfi's main harbor and beach area, where colorful fishing boats and pleasure craft dock alongside the historic Arsenale della Repubblica. The marina offers beautiful sea views, waterfront restaurants, and access to boat tours along the stunning Amalfi Coast.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most vibrant during summer months with boat tours and beach activities. Evening offers beautiful sunset views and romantic dining atmosphere.
sites.booking_tips: Free to walk around. Boat tours should be booked in advance during peak season. Parking can be expensive and limited.

sites.name: Arsenale della Repubblica
sites.description: A 13th-century shipyard that once built the powerful Amalfi Republic's naval fleet. Now a museum showcasing Amalfi's maritime history, medieval shipbuilding techniques, and the city's former role as a major Mediterranean trading power.
sites.seasonal_notes: Perfect for hot summer afternoons. The museum provides insight into Amalfi's golden age as a maritime republic.
sites.booking_tips: Small entrance fee. Guided tours available. Located near the marina for easy access. Check opening hours as they vary by season.

sites.name: Valle delle Ferriere
sites.description: A stunning natural reserve featuring waterfalls, ancient paper mills, and lush Mediterranean vegetation. This protected area showcases Amalfi's traditional paper-making industry and offers hiking trails through beautiful landscapes with views of the coast.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best visited in spring and autumn for comfortable hiking temperatures. Summer can be hot and crowded. Winter offers peaceful solitude.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Wear sturdy hiking shoes and bring water. Some trails require moderate fitness. Guided tours available.

sites.name: Spiaggia Grande
sites.description: Amalfi's main beach featuring dark volcanic sand and crystal-clear Mediterranean waters. The beach offers stunning views of the town's dramatic cliffside architecture and is perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and enjoying the coastal atmosphere.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peak season is July-August when beaches are crowded. May-June and September offer pleasant weather with fewer crowds. Winter visits are peaceful but cold for swimming.
sites.booking_tips: Public beach areas are free. Beach equipment rentals available. Arrive early for best spots during summer. Limited facilities compared to larger resorts.

sites.name: Museo della Carta
sites.description: A fascinating museum dedicated to Amalfi's historic paper-making tradition, housed in a 13th-century paper mill. Visitors can learn about the ancient techniques used to create the famous 'bambagina' paper and see demonstrations of traditional paper production.
sites.seasonal_notes: Perfect for hot summer afternoons or rainy days. The museum provides insight into one of Amalfi's most important historical industries.
sites.booking_tips: Small entrance fee. Guided tours and paper-making workshops available. Located in the historic center. Check for special events and demonstrations.

sites.name: Villa Rufolo
sites.description: A magnificent 13th-century villa with stunning gardens that inspired Wagner's 'Parsifal.' The villa features beautiful Moorish architecture, terraced gardens with panoramic sea views, and hosts the famous Ravello Festival concerts during summer months.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most beautiful in spring and early summer when gardens are in bloom. Summer offers evening concerts. Winter visits are peaceful with fewer crowds.
sites.booking_tips: Entrance fee required. Check concert schedule if interested in musical events. Photography allowed. Beautiful sunset views from the gardens.

sites.name: Sentiero degli Dei
sites.description: The famous 'Path of the Gods' hiking trail offering spectacular views of the Amalfi Coast, Capri, and the Mediterranean Sea. This challenging but rewarding trail connects Agerola to Nocelle, passing through beautiful landscapes and offering some of the best coastal views in Italy.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best in spring and autumn for comfortable temperatures. Summer can be very hot and crowded. Winter offers solitude but check weather conditions.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Requires good fitness level. Wear proper hiking shoes and bring water. Can be accessed from various points along the coast.

sites.name: Piazza del Duomo
sites.description: The heart of Amalfi, this beautiful square is dominated by the magnificent cathedral and surrounded by historic buildings, cafés, and shops. The square offers a perfect place to soak in the atmosphere, people-watch, and enjoy the architectural beauty of the town.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most atmospheric in the evening when locals and visitors gather. Summer brings street performers and increased activity. Winter offers peaceful charm.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Perfect for photography and people-watching. Many restaurants and cafés surround the square. Arrive early for dinner reservations.

sites.name: Grotta dello Smeraldo
sites.description: A stunning sea cave known for its emerald-green waters caused by underwater light filtering. Accessible by boat from Amalfi, the cave features beautiful stalactites and offers a unique perspective of the Amalfi Coast from the sea.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best visited in calm weather conditions. Summer offers the most boat departures. Spring and autumn provide pleasant temperatures and fewer crowds.
sites.booking_tips: Boat tours must be booked in advance. Weather dependent - tours may be cancelled in rough seas. Bring camera for the beautiful emerald waters.

sites.name: Chiesa di Santa Maria a Mare
sites.description: A charming 12th-century church located near the marina, featuring beautiful frescoes and a peaceful atmosphere. This smaller church offers a more intimate religious experience compared to the grand cathedral and provides insight into Amalfi's spiritual heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peaceful atmosphere year-round. Early morning offers the most spiritual experience. Summer brings more visitors but maintains its charm.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry. Modest dress required. Photography may be restricted during services. Located near the marina for easy access.

sites.name: Via Lorenzo d'Amalfi
sites.description: Amalfi's main shopping street featuring local crafts, ceramics, limoncello, and traditional souvenirs. This pedestrian-friendly street offers authentic Amalfi products including handmade paper, local ceramics, and regional specialties.
sites.seasonal_notes: Active year-round with shops open most days. Summer brings more tourists and street vendors. Winter offers more authentic local shopping experience.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Many shops offer local specialties like limoncello and handmade paper. Bargaining not expected but some shops may offer discounts.

sites.name: Torre dello Ziro
sites.description: A medieval watchtower perched on a hill above Amalfi, offering spectacular panoramic views of the town, coast, and sea. This historic defensive structure provides insight into Amalfi's strategic importance and offers some of the best photo opportunities in the area.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most beautiful at sunset for photography. Spring and autumn offer comfortable temperatures for the uphill walk. Summer can be hot for the climb.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Requires moderate fitness for uphill walk. Wear comfortable shoes. Best reached by foot from the town center.

sites.name: Piazza dei Dogi
sites.description: A smaller, more intimate square featuring historic buildings and the remains of Amalfi's medieval palace. This quiet square offers a glimpse into the town's former political importance and provides a peaceful retreat from the main tourist areas.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peaceful year-round with fewer tourists. Early morning offers the most authentic atmosphere. Summer brings some visitors but maintains its charm.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Perfect for quiet contemplation and photography. Located away from main tourist routes. Historical information available on plaques.

sites.name: Chiesa di San Salvatore de' Birecto
sites.description: A small but historically significant church dating from the 10th century, featuring beautiful Byzantine-style architecture and frescoes. This church represents one of Amalfi's oldest religious buildings and showcases the town's early Christian heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Peaceful atmosphere year-round. Early morning offers the most spiritual experience. Summer brings some visitors but maintains its intimate feel.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry. Modest dress required. Photography may be restricted. Located in the historic center near other attractions.

sites.name: Fontana di Sant'Andrea
sites.description: A beautiful 18th-century fountain dedicated to Saint Andrew, featuring intricate stonework and traditional Amalfi design elements. Located near the cathedral, this fountain serves as a gathering point and represents the town's artistic and cultural heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Afternoon offers good lighting for photography. Summer brings more activity around the fountain area.
sites.booking_tips: Free to visit. Perfect for photography and people-watching. Located in the heart of the historic center. Can be crowded during peak tourist season.

sites.name: Punta Campanella
sites.description: A stunning natural promontory marking the western end of the Amalfi Coast, offering spectacular views of Capri, the Sorrentine Peninsula, and the Mediterranean Sea. This protected marine area provides excellent hiking opportunities and some of the most dramatic coastal scenery in Italy.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most beautiful at sunset for photography. Spring and autumn offer comfortable temperatures for hiking. Summer can be hot but offers the clearest views.
sites.booking_tips: Free access. Requires good fitness for hiking. Wear appropriate footwear. Best reached by car or organized tour. Marine reserve restrictions apply.
